title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: (See Monastery, vol. i.) From this bridge the Girthgate, a path to the sanctuary of Soutra, runs up the valley of Allan Water, and over the moors to Soutra Ilill.

title: Oliver Cromwell's letters and speeches: with elucidations.
author: Cromwell, Oliver
snippet: His chief abode was about and inthe Mountains of Pentland and Soutra.' — And again, from Perth,19th December, 1650 : ' Memorandum, That Augustin departedfrom Fife with a party of six-score horse ; crossed at Blacknesson Friday, 13th December ; forced Cromwell's guards ; killedeighty men to the Enemy ; put-in thirty-six men to EdinburghCastle, with all sorts of spices, and some other things ; took thirty-five horses and five prisoners, which he sent to Perth the 14th ofthis instant.'

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: " 'Deed, sir," observed the other, " ye're a cleverman, an' it wasna' mony that could hae plannedyon trap we laid at Soutra; ye'll excuse me forsayin' sae, but ye'll be a cleverer man still ifye trap Wull Scott ance he's safe in Jeddart;but we'll see, we'll see !"

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: Soutra, and surprise them while they wereenjoying their liquor in fancied security, wasthe next move; but the way in which it wascarried out was in the best style of generalship.

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: Nations, towns, vdlages, people, all must bow tothe inevitable changes that are brought aboutby time; like this village of Soutra, once so

title: Cleekim Inn. A tale of smuggling in the '45
author: Dibdin, James C.
snippet: At the present day, scarcely a stone stands onanother to mark what was once the prosperousand gay vdlage of Soutra, famous in its time asa place of sanctuary7, and dedicated, by thosewho found it convenient to breathe freedom fromdanger in the mountain air it afforded, to feasting and revelry.
